benchmark_details.name: Distributive Fairness in Large Language Models: Evaluating Alignment with Human Values
benchmark_details.overview: This paper examines the alignment of large language model (LLM) responses with fundamental fairness concepts such as equitability, envy-freeness, and Rawlsian maximin, providing a comparative benchmark of their ability to reflect these measures in resource allocation tasks.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate the alignment of large language models with human perceptions of fairness in resource allocation tasks.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The paper does not discuss specific limitations of the benchmark results.

data.source: Instances from the dataset developed by Herreiner and Puppe (2007).
data.annotation: Generated using large language models reacting to predefined allocation tasks.

metrics: Fairness metrics based on equitability, envy-freeness, Rawlsian maximin
methodology.calculation: Fairness and efficiency based on utility values assigned to different allocations by human and LLM responses.
methodology.interpretation: Results indicating models' preferences regarding fairness principles are compared against human responses to gauge alignment.
methodology.validation: Comparison of LLM outputs against human preferences across multiple allocation tasks.
